newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Supreme Court to demand "dirty war" files.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Supreme Court to demand "dirty war" files.

text.p: Spain's Supreme Court said on Friday it would ask the government to hand over secret files purporting to prove the former Socialist administration set up death squads which waged a "dirty war" against Basque separatists.
The court said it wanted to examine the secret service files before making a decision on whether it would demand that they be declassified.

Lower courts are calling for the declassification of some 20 documents that give details of a secret campaign of assassinations and kidnappings against guerrillas of ETA (Basque Homeland and Freedom) in the 1980s.
The ruling conservative Popular Party (PP) and the previous Socialist administration have refused, citing reasons of state security.
Justice Minister Margarita Mariscal de Gante said on Friday the government would respect the decision of the Supreme Court.
"For a long time the cabinet has said that it would obey their decision," she told reporters.

Documents already leaked to the press suggest the Socialist government of Felipe Gonzalez was responsible for organising death squads known as the Anti-Terrorist Liberation Groups (GAL), which killed 28 people between 1983 and 1987.
If the government hands over the papers, it will be the first time the judges have had access to information classified as state secrets, local media said.
The court, comprising 33 judges, is due to announce its decision on whether it will insist the government declassify the papers in the next few weeks.
